processing_metadata.publication: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/Nomura

passages.text: Implies that focus is already on next- FY earnings / gap in factor returns has consistently widened during previous periods of earnings forecast improvement

Looking at the year to date we observe that forecast E/P (the reciprocal of forward P/E), a key flow value factor, languished from the time of the tariff shock on 2 April through around the end of June. One reasonable interpretation of this is that valuations were not effective because of the uncertain earnings outlook. Since July, however, B/P (the inverse of P/B), a stock value factor, has been performing well.

Normally, the forecast E/P factor that we monitor prioritizes next- FY forecasts, but in Figure 1 we compare next- FY forecast E/P factor returns with current- FY forecast E/P factor returns. This shows that next- FY forecast E/P factor returns were inferior in the first half of 2025, and this trend worsened immediately after the tariff shock of 2 April. This may have been due to investors taking the view that there was greater uncertainty about earnings in subsequent years than in the current fiscal year. However, this gap narrowed as 25/3 Q4 results were released, and the gap between the two has been widening recently, with next- FY forecast E/P as at advantage since July.
Fig. 1: Next-FY forecast E/P and current-FY forecast E/P factor returns
Note: Unjerse is TOPIX 500 constituents. Data for 2025 onwards. Source: Nomura, based on QUICK, Bloomberg, and IFIS data
Japan quantitative research

There has been a lot of discussion recently about the impact of tariffs on earnings at individual companies. Since slightly before the 26/3 Q1 results season, however, share prices appear to be reacting to undervaluation based on next- FY earnings. In other words, investors may have abruptly started to shift their attention in terms of earnings to next- FY forecasts rather than current- FY forecasts.

In the past we have also observed such sudden shifts in investor attention toward the future. Figure 2 shows the long- term cumulative spread between next- FY forecast E/P and current- FY forecast E/P factor returns. Our analysis shows that when the revision index bottomed out and then improved substantially into positive territory in 2016 H2 and 2020 H2 (Figure 3), the next- FY forecast E/P factor tended to become more effective. When the revision index can be expected to improve sharply (implying a steeper improvement in future earnings), optimism about the earnings outlook apparently prevails, and interest in future earnings tends to increase. In other words, we should expect this factor return spread to continue to widen. Figure 4 shows stocks with a substantial gap between next- FY forecast E/P and current- FY E/P, and that appear undervalued based on next- FY forecast E/P.
Fig. 2: Cumulative spread between next-FY forecast E/P and current-FY forecast E/P factor returns
Note: Universe is TOPIX 500 constituents. Data for 2015 onwards. Source: Nomura, based on QUICK, Bloomberg, and IFIS data
Fig. 3: Revision index

Note: Universe is TOPIX 500 constituents. Revisions are based on current-FY IBES forecasts and are compared to forecasts 12 weeks prior. Revision index \(=\) (number of companies with upward revisions minus number of companies with downward revisions) / universe. Data for 2015 onwards. Source: Nomura, based on QUICK, Bloomberg, and IFIS data
Fig.4: Stocks that look undervalued with next-FY forecast E/P higher than current-FY forecast E/P

the analyst expects the stock to underperform the Benchmark over the next 12 months. Investment trusts invest mainly in securities such as Japanese and foreign equities and bonds, whose prices fluctuate. In interest rate swap transactions and USD/JPY basis swap transactions ("interest rate swap transactions, etc."), only the agreed transaction payments shall be made on the settlement dates. Some interest rate swap transactions, etc. may require pledging of margin collateral. In some of these cases, transaction payments may exceed the amount of collateral. There shall be no advance notification of required collateral value or collateral ratios as they vary depending on the transaction. Interest rate swap transactions, etc. carry the risk of losses owing to fluctuations in market prices in the interest rate, currency and other markets, as well as reference indices. Losses incurred as such may exceed the value of margin collateral, in which case margin calls may be triggered. In the event that both parties agree to enter a replacement (or termination) transaction, the interest rates received (paid) under the new arrangement may differ from those in the original arrangement, even if terms other than the interest rates are identical to those in the original transaction. Risks vary by transaction. Please thoroughly read the written materials provided, such as documents delivered before making a contract and disclosure statements.

In OTC transactions of credit default swaps (CDS), no sales commission will be charged. When entering into CDS transactions, the protection buyer will be required to pledge or entrust an agreed amount of margin collateral. In some of these cases, the transaction payments may exceed the amount of margin collateral. There shall be no advance notification of required collateral value or collateral ratios as they vary depending on the financial position of the protection buyer. CDS transactions carry the risk of losses owing to changes in the credit position of some or all of the referenced entities, and/or fluctuations of the interest rate market. The amount the protection buyer receives in the event that the CDS is triggered by a credit event may undercut the total amount of premiums that he/she has paid in the course of the transaction. Similarly, the amount the protection seller pays in the event of a credit event may exceed the total amount of premiums that he/she has received in the transaction. All other conditions being equal, the amount of premiums that the protection buyer pays and that received by the protection seller shall differ. In principle, CDS transactions will be limited to financial instruments business operators and qualified institutional investors.
